Why does he conclude the portion of Scripture? It almost, someone could almost look at it and say, well, it's kind of out of place. No, it's right in place because he's rehearsing his salvation, he's rehearsing what Christ did for him and how God gave him mercy and grace and saved him and gave him purpose and who he was before he remembered, but he remembered that what he was before does not define who he is now because there was something that took place on the road to Damascus. He was saved by the grace of God. Therefore, he says, now unto the King, eternal, immortal, invisible, the only wise God, be honor and glory forever and ever. Amen. In Philippians chapter number 4, he begins in verse number 1, he says, Therefore, my brethren, dearly beloved, and longed for my joy and crown, so stand fast in the Lord, my dearly beloved. I beseech Jodeas and beseech Syntyche, that they be of the same mind in the Lord. And I entreat thee also, true yoke fellow, help those women which labored with me in the gospel with Clement also and with other my fellow laborers, notice what he says, whose names are written in the book of life. Do you know what the next verse is? Verse 4, rejoice in the Lord always. And again, I say, rejoice. Is it not of interest to you this morning that when Jesus is teaching in Luke chapter number 9, those 70 are sent out, they return with joy, and Jesus says, listen, yes, you've been given power over that, but don't rejoice in that, rather rejoice that your names are written in heaven. We find that Paul says to the believers in Philippi, as he's writing to them, he speaks of those whose names are in the book of life, and he says, rejoice in the Lord always. And again, I say rejoice. And then when he shares his testimony in 1 Timothy chapter number 1 with Timothy, and he says, here's what has happened to me, I've been saved by the grace of God. My name was written in the book of life, therefore I rejoice. But Paul, this is against you, but Paul, this has happened, but Paul, they are going to, my name is written in the book of life. I've been saved by the grace of God. D.L. Moody famously, it's said of him, and I'm not sure how you would respond to such a situation, but it is said that D.L. Moody was on the streets of Chicago, and a man pulled a gun on him, and held the gun right to him, and he looked at that man and said, you can't threaten me with heaven. That's amazing. That's a man that knew that his name was written in the book of life, a man that had assurance of his salvation. And this morning, when we think about this passage of Scripture, and that great declaration that is given in verse number 15 of the text, now this is a faithful saying and worthy of all acceptation, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners, of whom I am chief. I wonder this morning, when we recognize what we've received, as Paul did, when we remember who we were and what Christ did for us, how does it impact our rejoicing? Can I tell you this morning, 2 Corinthians says, today is the day of salvation. Today, your name could be written in the book of life, because Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners. He loved us so much. He knew our condition, but He loved us so much, and He went to a cruel cross. He bled and He died. He was buried and He rose, conquering sin, death, and the grave. And He says, for whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved. This morning, maybe there's someone that needs to be saved this morning. For many of us, we've already been saved.
